content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

# Question

You are given a markdown-formatted text `md`. Write a function `q_and_a_extractor` to extract all text in the markdown sections Question and Answer (starting with `# Question` and `# Answer`, respectively) and return the answer in a tuple like `(question,answer)`. Strip any leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.

```julia
function q_and_a_extractor(md)
    question_start = findfirst(r"^# Question\b", md, 1))
    
    if question_start === nothing
        return ()
    end
    
    question_end = findnext(r"^\n\n", md[question_start:end]), 1) || length(md)
    
    answer_start = findfirst(r"^# Answer\b", md[question_start+2:end]), 1)
    
    if answer_start === nothing
        return (strip(md[question_start+2:question_end]])),)
    end
    
    answer_end = findnext(r"^\n\n", md[answer_start:end]), 1) || length(md)

    return (strip(md[question_start+2:question_end]])), strip(md[answer_start+2:answer_end]])))
end
```

This function `q_and_a_extractor` takes a markdown-formatted text `md` and extracts the Question and Answer sections. It returns the answers in a tuple.

It uses regular expressions to find the start and end positions of the Question and Answer sections. The `strip` function is used to remove leading spaces and newlines from the extracted text.
